articles.headline: Obama May Add 30,000 Troops in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: President Obama’s aides signaled that he would send as many as 30,000 additional American troops, but the total number remained in flux.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s aides signaled that he would send as many as 30,000 additional American troops, but the total number remained in flux.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that he was determined to “finish the job” in Afghanistan, and his aides signaled to allies that he would send as many as 25,000 to 30,000 additional American troops there even as they cautioned that the final number remained in flux.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Airlines Pay for Stranding Passengers
articles.snippet: The Department of Transportation levied $175,000 in penalties against three airlines for their role in leaving passengers overnight on a plane at Rochester, Minn.
articles.abstract: The Department of Transportation levied $175,000 in penalties against three airlines for their role in leaving passengers overnight on a plane at Rochester, Minn.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Transportation Department imposed its first penalties for runway delays Tuesday, collecting $175,000 from three airlines for leaving 47 passengers of a regional jet stranded overnight in Rochester, Minn.

articles.headline: U.S. Looks to Australia on Credit Card Fees
articles.snippet: After a law forced a cut in transaction fees, some merchants and banks added new charges for customers that were, sometimes, higher than the old ones.
articles.abstract: After a law forced a cut in transaction fees, some merchants and banks added new charges for customers that were, sometimes, higher than the old ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY  When Steve Franklin bought four plane tickets on Qantas last June, he faced an unexpected expense: a surcharge of 7.70 Australian dollars on each of the 136.70 dollar ($126) tickets  just for using his Visa credit card.

articles.headline: Seeking Deals, Holiday Fliers Get Early Start
articles.snippet: The holiday crush at the nation’s airports has taken hold several days earlier as travelers sought less expensive flights.
articles.abstract: The holiday crush at the nation’s airports has taken hold several days earlier as travelers sought less expensive flights.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Airports big and small will be packed on Wednesday, just as they are every year on the day before Thanksgiving.

articles.headline: Galleon Chief Attacks Government’s Case Against Him
articles.snippet: Raj Rajaratnam, the founder of the Galleon Group, said his hedge fund had based its investments on research and not, as the authorities claim, on inside information.
articles.abstract: Raj Rajaratnam, the founder of the Galleon Group, said his hedge fund had based its investments on research and not, as the authorities claim, on inside information.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five weeks after he was arrested on charges of masterminding a vast insider-trading scheme, Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire money manager, answered his accusers on Tuesday with a sharp-edged attack on the government’s case against him.

articles.headline: On ‘The Biggest Loser,’ Health Can Take Back Seat
articles.snippet: Some contestants of NBC’s “The Biggest Loser” say that dangerous weight-loss techniques are common.
articles.abstract: Some contestants of NBC’s “The Biggest Loser” say that dangerous weight-loss techniques are common.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  When more than 40 former contestants from “The Biggest Loser” gather Wednesday for a reunion television special, the winner of the program’s first season, Ryan C. Benson, who lost 122 of his 330-pound starting weight, will be absent. Mr. Benson is now back above 300 pounds but he thinks he has been shunned by the show because he publicly admitted that he dropped some of the weight by fasting and dehydrating himself to the point that he was urinating blood.

articles.headline: Budget Hawks Have a Buffet of Options With Health Bill
articles.snippet: Senators who say they’re serious about reducing health care costs have plenty of opportunities in the current bills to fulfill their goals.
articles.abstract: Senators who say they’re serious about reducing health care costs have plenty of opportunities in the current bills to fulfill their goals.

articles.headline: Toyota Will Fix or Replace 4 Million Gas Pedals
articles.snippet: Toyota aims to resolve a problem with unintended acceleration that has stripped some of the luster off the carmaker’s reputation for reliability.
articles.abstract: Toyota aims to resolve a problem with unintended acceleration that has stripped some of the luster off the carmaker’s reputation for reliability.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Toyota said Wednesday it would have to fix the gas pedals of about four million vehicles, including the Camry, to resolve a widespread problem with unintended acceleration.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley
